Controls.Description: Use of public IP address and ports should be carefully reviewed
Controls.Rationale: Public IP address provides direct access over the internet exposing the container to all type of attacks over the public network.
Controls.Recommendation: Add public IP address and ports to a container only as required. Ensure that the resulting data flows are carefully reviewed.

Controls.Description: Make sure container images (including nested images) are from a trustworthy source
Controls.Rationale: If a container runs an untrusted image (or an untrusted nested image), it can violate integrity of the infrastructure and lead to all types of security attacks.
Controls.Recommendation: Ensure that the image source(s) for the image comprising the container are trustworthy. Review image configurations carefully for any misconfigurations.

Controls.Description: Make sure container images are hosted on a trustworthy registry that has strong authentication, authorization and data protection mechanisms
Controls.Rationale: If a container image is served from an untrusted registry, the image itself may not be trustworthy. Running such a compromised image can lead to loss of sensitive enterprise data.
Controls.Recommendation: Ensure that the registry, which hosts the image, is trustworthy. Review registry configurations carefully for any misconfigurations related to authentication, authorization, etc.

Controls.Description: A container group must contain only containers which trust each other
Controls.Rationale: Containers hosted in the same container group can monitor traffic of other containers within the group and can also access the file system of the host OS. Hence a container group must not host containers which do not trust each other. In other words, do not mix containers across trust boundaries in the same group.
Controls.Recommendation: Carefully review the role and privileges required by each container in a container group. If the privilege levels and access requirements are different, then consider segregating the containers into separate groups.
